condition.description:
Pain is a feeling set off in the nervous system. Acute pain lets you know that you may be injured or have a problem you need to take care of. Chronic pain is different. The pain signals go on for weeks, months, or even years. The original cause may have been an injury or infection. There may be an ongoing cause of pain, such as arthritis or cancer. But in some cases there is no clear cause.

Problems that cause chronic pain include

  • Headache
  • Low back strain
  • Cancer
  • Arthritis
  • Pain from nerve damage

Chronic pain usually cannot be cured. But treatments can help. They include medicines, acupuncture, electrical stimulation and surgery. Other treatments include psychotherapy, relaxation and meditation therapy, biofeedback, and behavior modification.

NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke
condition.name: Chronic pain

carousel_items: Fentanyl should only be used for people whose pain is not controlled by other opioid medications for at least one week.
For pain, the patch takes 12 hours to start working and all other forms start working in 30 minutes or less.
If using the patch, keep it away from heat sources like heating pads, or else it'll cause the medication to be unsafely released into your skin.
Never stop taking Fentanyl suddenly or else you'll have withdrawal effects. To stop taking it, you'll need to lower your dose slowly.
Never drink alcohol when using Fentanyl.
Just one dose can be harmful or fatal to children, so store and dispose of this medication in a way that children can't get to it.

basics.benefits_moa: Fentanyl is an opioid (narcotic) medicine that works in the brain to lower pain perception.
basics.bottom_line: Fentanyl is an excellent pain reliever, but should only be used by people  who've tried other opioid pain medications and still need more relief.
downsides: Fentanyl isn't for everyone. It's a really strong pain medication and taking too much can be deadly.
It doesn't provide quick pain relief.
Often causes drowsiness and constipation. If using it long-term, use a stool softener.
Like all opioids, don't use when pregnant, since the baby can become dependent on it and have withdrawal symptoms after birth.
Shouldn't be used for people with breathing problems (like asthma and COPD), a slow heart rate, or in the elderly.
If using the patch, you won't be able to get the medicine out of your body quickly in case of an overdose.

upsides: It's used for people who have tried other opioid medications, but still need stronger pain relief.
Fentanyl is stronger than morphine, works quickly, and doesn't cause as many stomach problems.
It's available in many dosage forms, including a patch, injection, film, nasal spray, and lollipop.
The Fentanyl patch provides long-term pain relief and lowers the number of times you need to take pain medications each day.

drugs.name: fentanyl

carousel_items_processed.orig: Fentanyl should only be used for people whose pain is not controlled by other opioid medications for at least one week.
For pain, the patch takes 12 hours to start working and all other forms start working in 30 minutes or less.
If using the patch, keep it away from heat sources like heating pads, or else it'll cause the medication to be unsafely released into your skin.
Never stop taking Fentanyl suddenly or else you'll have withdrawal effects. To stop taking it, you'll need to lower your dose slowly.
Never drink alcohol when using Fentanyl.
Just one dose can be harmful or fatal to children, so store and dispose of this medication in a way that children can't get to it.

risks_warnings.title: Death from lack of oxygen to the body (respiratory depression)
risks_warnings.description: Taking too much Fentanyl can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. Fentanyl should be swallowed whole, don't ever crush or chew. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Fentanyl. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes. Always check with your doctor before starting any new medicines or supplements.
risk_factors: Current use of medicine that affects liver enzyme CYP 3A4
People with not enough thyroid hormones

description_processed.orig: Taking too much Fentanyl can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Fentanyl. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes. Always check with your doctor before starting any new medicines or supplements.

risks_warnings.title: Death from overdose
risks_warnings.description: Even one dose of Fentanyl can be too much for children. Keep the medicine out of reach from children. If you suspect your child has taken Fentanyl, watch for decreased activity, extreme tiredness, and lips and fingers turning blue from low oxygen. Go to a hospital immediately and the doctors can give a medicine that reverses the effects of Fentanyl until the effects wear off.

risks_warnings.title: Death in newborn babies from opioid withdrawal (Neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome)
risks_warnings.description: Let your doctor know if you have used Fentanyl during pregnancy. Your baby may need special care after birth from experts in this area.

description_processed.orig: Let your doctor know if you have used Fentanyl during pregnancy. Your baby may need special care after birth from experts in this area.

risks_warnings.title: Tolerance, dependence, and addiction
risks_warnings.description: Extended-release and long-acting opioid pain relievers like Fentanyl have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. Your body can develop tolerance to Fentanyl, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You may become physically dependent on Fentanyl if you have been using it continuously for 2 to 3 weeks or longer, which means that you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly with the help of a doctor. Take only the prescribed dose. People with a history of drug abuse shouldn't take Fentanyl if an alternative medicine is available.
risk_factors: Taking more than the prescribed dose

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Fentanyl lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Fentanyl can lower your blood pressure. You may feel dizzy, lightheaded. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change position slowly, such as going from sitting to standing since that is when you will feel the low blood pressure the most. If symptoms continues for more than a few doses, another pain medicine may be better for you.

carousel_items: Long-acting opioid for moderate to severe pain.
May not be the best choice for people who have never taken opioids, or who've only taken shorter-acting opioids for pain.
May be part of a complete program to reduce opioid dependence.
For short-term treatment of opioid dependence, the target dose is 40mg for 2-3 days, then reduced every 2 days.
For long-term drug detoxification treatment the dose is increased until withdrawal symptoms stay away for 24 hours.
Dosing can vary widely, but for most people the general range is 80-120mg daily.
Take exactly as your doctor instructs and don’t take more than you're prescribed.
Can make you dizzy or drowsy.
Avoid activities that need you to be fully alert until you know how it affects you.
Don't mix with alcohol or other sedating drugs.
Constipation is common and may not go away while you're taking this medicine. Drinking lots of water and taking laxatives can help.
Talk to your doctor if it doesn't help enough for your pain.
If you need to stop taking this medicine, work with your doctor to slowly lower your dose. It'll help you avoid withdrawal symptoms.
Careful reduction from your maintenance dose is important. It shouldn't be more than 10% of the total daily dose, reduced every 10 to 14 days.

basics.benefits_moa: Methadone is an opioid medicine (similar to morphine) that works in the brain to lower pain perception. Because withdrawal from Methadone is slower, takes longer, and is less severe than other opioids, it's used under the care of a doctor to treat opioid addiction.
basics.bottom_line: Methadone works well for moderate to severe pain especially nerve-related and complex pain and is effective for maintenance opioid addiction treatment. You need to be careful with dosing.
downsides: Need to use it “around-the-clock for pain control not “as needed”.
Even one dose is too much for child or pet and is a medical emergency so store out of their reach.
Can cause slowed breathing, coma and death from overdose, especially if you mix with other nervous system depressants.
Has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control especially if you have cardiovascular disease (previous heart attack, stroke, fast/uncontrolled heart rate, or irregular heart beat).
Can reduce your ability to focus, think, and react so avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medicine affects you.
Not safe to take if you're pregnant or breast-feeding and can increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome in women with a history of long-term opioid use.

May cause you to become tolerant (more medicine is needed to treat the same pain) and physically dependent if you’ve used it for a while so don’t stop talking it suddenly or you may feel withdrawal symptoms.
Can cause your blood pressure drop suddenly if you change positions quickly.
Certain prescription and over-the-counter medicines can change the amount of medicine in your body and cause either overdose or withdrawal.

Not safe to take if you're pregnant or breast-feeding and can increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome in women with a history of long-term opioid use.

May cause you to become tolerant (more medicine is needed to treat the same pain) and physically dependent if you’ve used it for a while so don’t stop talking it suddenly or you may feel withdrawal symptoms.
Can cause your blood pressure drop suddenly if you change positions quickly.
Certain prescription and over-the-counter medicines can change the amount of medicine in your body and cause either overdose or withdrawal.

upsides: Relieves pain and treats opioid addiction.
Good option for people who don't get pain relief with more-common opioids, have side effects or allergies with other options, or have nerve pain (neuropathic pain).
Even low doses are more effective than placebo at treating shooting, burning pain.
Less constipating than other opioid medicines to treat pain.
Available as a generic medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems (arrhythmias)
risks_warnings.description: Methadone has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control. Seek medical attention immediately if you feel faint and have palpitations.

risks_warnings.title: Drug interactions
risks_warnings.description: Some medicines can affect enzymes that break down Methadone. Certain drugs to treat infections, HIV, and seizures can change the amount of Methadone in the body and cause either overdose or withdrawal. Tell your doctor about any prescription or over-the-counter medications you are taking.
risk_factors: Taking drugs that slow or stop breakdown the breakdown of Methadone

Tell your doctor about any prescription or over-the-counter medications you are taking.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Methadone can cause severe low blood pressure, fainting, and a drop blood pressure when you change positions, called orthostatic hypotension. You may be more sensitive if you're already taking medicine to lower your blood pressure so be careful. It's important that you tell your doctor about these symptoms before changing your dose or stopping your medication suddenly.
risk_factors: Taking drugs that lower blood pressure

risks_warnings.title: Neonatal withdrawal syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Methadone passes into breast milk. Women with a history of long-term opioid use increase the risk of neonatal withdrawal syndrome. Symptoms include irritability, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor and lack of weight gain. Opioid withdrawal in infants is a life-threatening emergency and needs medical help right away.
risk_factors: Long-term use of opioids in mother

risks_warnings.title: Death from overdose
risks_warnings.description: Even 1 dose of Methadone can be too much for a child so store out of reach from children. In adults, raising the dose too quickly, high doses or mixing with alcohol or drugs that interact causes overdose and death. If you suspect a child has taken Methadone, or an adult has taken too much, watch them for decreased activity, extreme tiredness small pupils, and lips and fingers turning blue from low oxygen. Call 911 or go to a hospital immediately. Doctors can give a medicine that reverses the effects of Methadone until the effects wear off.
risk_factors: Mixing with alcohol or drugs that interact with Methadone

risks_warnings.title: Abuse, tolerance, and addiction
risks_warnings.description: Long-acting opioids like Methadone have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. Your body can develop tolerance to Methadone, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You can become physically dependent on Methadone if you have been using it continuously for more than 1-2 weeks, meaning you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly and taking the exact dose your doctor prescribed. People taking Methadone for pain with a history of drug abuse should ask their doctor about other medicine choices.

risks_warnings.title: Tolerance, dependence, and addiction
risks_warnings.description: Extended-release and long-acting opioid pain relievers like Morphine have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. Your body can develop tolerance to Morphine, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You may become physically dependent on Morphine if you have been using it continuously for 2-3 weeks or longer, which means that you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly with the help of a doctor. Take only the prescribed dose. People with a history of drug abuse shouldn't take Morphine if an alternative medicine is available.

You shouldn’t take Oxycodone if you've had an allergic reaction to certain opioids like codeine, hydromorphone, hydrocodone, levorphanol, and oxymorphone. Talk to your doctor about other pain medicine choices.

basics.benefits_moa: Tramadol is an atypical opioid pain reliever. Researchers don't know exactly how it works, but it alters certain brain chemicals to lower pain perception and improve mood.
basics.bottom_line: Tramadol works well to treat severe pain and mood changes. Although it's a little weaker than other opioids, it can still be addictive.
downsides: Some people think it's weaker than other opioid pain medications. It can also cause more upset stomach.

Like other opioid pain relievers, Tramadol has a high risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. It should only be used for severe pain that requires daily, around-the-clock treatment once alternative treatments haven't worked.
It isn't used for short-term, as-needed pain relief.
It's a controlled substance regulated by the federal government. This means that your use of Tramadol will be tracked to prevent potential prescription abuse.
To get Tramadol in the pharmacy, you'll need to bring in a paper prescription directly from your doctor.

risks_warnings.title: Serotonin syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Serotonin syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused when there's too much serotonin active in the brain. Your risk goes up if you use Tramadol with other medications that affect serotonin (other antidepressants, lithium, triptans, St. John's wort). Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Go to the hopspital right away if you have symptoms.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic (anaphylactoid) reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rare, sudden allergic reactions (including death) can occur, usually after the first dose. Symptoms include difficulty breathing; swelling of the face, tongue, and throat; and itching or hives. This is a medical emergency. People with sensitivity to phenylketones and phenylalanine should NOT take the orally disintegrating tablet (Rybix ODT). This formulation contains phenylalanine in an inactive ingredient.

risks_warnings.title: Withdrawal

Discontinue slowly with the help of a doctor.

carousel_items: Take at bedtime to avoid some of its side effects.
Can cause dizziness, drowsiness, constipation, and weight gain.
Stop taking it slowly to avoid getting withdrawal symptoms.
Tell your doctor if you notice sudden mood changes or unusual thoughts.

basics.benefits_moa: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). Researchers don't know exactly how it works. It may change serotonin and norepinephrine activity in the brain, which regulates mood and pain perception. It also has sedative effects.
basics.bottom_line: Amitriptyline is an older antidepressant that's sometimes used to treat pain and sleep problems, but it can have more side effects than similar medications.
downsides: When used for depression, Amitriptyline causes more side effects and has a higher risk of overdose than other antidepressants. It's usually used when other medications haven't worked.
It's more likely to cause sleepiness, nausea, constipation, diarrhea, and weight gain (1 to 5 pounds) than other antidepressants.
People age 65 and older have a higher risk for this medication's side effects.
Like most antidepressants, it can cause a higher risk of suicidal thoughts and behavior for people age 24 and younger.
The first antidepressant you try doesn't always work or it can cause side effects you really don't like. You might need to try a few different medications until you find one that works for you.

downsides_processed.orig: When used for depression, Amitriptyline causes more side effects and has a higher risk of overdose than other antidepressants. It's usually used when other medications haven't worked.
It's more likely to cause sleepiness, nausea, constipation, diarrhea, and weight gain (1 to 5 pounds) than other antidepressants.
People age 65 and older have a higher risk for this medication's side effects.
Like most antidepressants, it can cause a higher risk of suicidal thoughts and behavior for people age 24 and younger.
The first antidepressant you try doesn't always work or it can cause side effects you really don't like. You might need to try a few different medications until you find one that works for you.

upsides: Low doses work well to treat certain kinds of chronic pain. It can take 2 weeks to feel the full effects of the medication.
Low doses of Amitriptyline start working in 45 minutes to help you sleep better.
Six out of every ten people who use an antidepressant for the first time find that it works for them.

drugs.one_liner: Improves mood and relieves certain kinds of pain.

userStories.tip: Could not wake up and function properly. Never again.

Start really low (5 mg) and increase slowly (5 mg increase) every week to two weeks to avoid foggy brain feeling. I took it once before and didn't do this. I quit after several weeks because of foggy brain thing. This time - no problems.
Some people use this to prevent their headaches. It works for some, but didn't for me. I'm not saying it won't be worth it for you, but I wasn't helped.
Active with familial arthritis, fibromyalgia, old injury.

userStories.identifier: 25 year old with undiagnosable hip pain
userStories.tip: Makes you really sleepy until you adjust to it.
Used to treat undiagnosable hip pain that has occurred for 8 years.
It sure works for preventing migrains but it made me gain weight.
First few weeks are disruptive but after that it works great

My migraines have reduced in frequency and duration so much that it feels like a miracle. My doctor titrated me up to 25mcg and I take it every night before I go to bed. Love it! It has given me my life back!

I'm using this to treat depression, and insomnia which was caused by my primary medication. I take half of a 5mg tablet before bed and it knocks me out. Anymore and I'm very tired the next day. It has worked perfectly for my needs.
Been an insomniac all my life. Very little results from anything else.
Helped sleep at bedtime. Not as effective as Trazodone, but kept me asleep without waking up in pain.

carousel_items_processed.orig: Take at bedtime to avoid some of its side effects.
Can cause dizziness, drowsiness, constipation, and weight gain.
Stop taking it slowly to avoid getting withdrawal symptoms.
Tell your doctor if you notice sudden mood changes or unusual thoughts.

risks_warnings.title: Suicidal thoughts or behavior
risks_warnings.description: Amitriptyline may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior. Watch for worsening depression or any unusual changes in mood or behavior, especially during the first few months of treatment or when the dose changes. Report anything concerning to a doctor immediately. Amitriptyline is not approved for use in children younger than age 18.

description_processed.orig: Amitriptyline may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior. Watch for worsening depression or any unusual changes in mood or behavior, especially during the first few months of treatment or when the dose changes. Report anything concerning to a doctor immediately. Amitriptyline is not approved for use in children younger than age 18.

risks_warnings.title: Mania
risks_warnings.description: Sometimes, depression is the first symptom of bipolar disorder. Treating someone with bipolar disorder with an antidepressant alone can cause a manic episode (great excitement, euphoria, delusions, and overactivity). Make sure your doctor has screened you for a personal or family history of bipolar disorder or symptoms, and a family history of suicide.

description_processed.orig: Sometimes, depression is the first symptom of bipolar disorder. Treating someone with bipolar disorder with an antidepressant alone can cause a manic episode (great excitement, euphoria, delusions, and overactivity). Make sure your doctor has screened you for a personal or family history of bipolar disorder or symptoms, and a family history of suicide.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Amitriptyline has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control compared to other antidepressants. If you have a history of cardiovascular disease (including previous heart attack, stroke, fast/uncontrolled heart rate, or irregular heartbeat), talk to your doctor before use.

description_processed.orig: Amitriptyline has a higher risk of affecting heart rate control compared to other antidepressants. If you have a history of cardiovascular disease (including previous heart attack, stroke, fast/uncontrolled heart rate, or irregular heartbeat), talk to your doctor before use.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Dizziness and falls may occur due to a sudden drop in blood pressure when you change positions, such as going from sitting to standing. This is called orthostatic hypotension. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change position slowly until your body is used to the medicine. If symptoms persist, a different medication may be better for you.

description_processed.orig: Dizziness and falls may occur due to a sudden drop in blood pressure when you change positions, such as going from sitting to standing. This is called orthostatic hypotension. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change position slowly until your body is used to the medicine. If symptoms persist, a different medication may be better for you.

risks_warnings.title: Anticholinergic effects
risks_warnings.description: Amitriptyline blocks acetylcholine, a nervous system chemical involved in many major bodily functions. Therefore, this medication commonly causes symptoms such as dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, dizziness, and higher risk of falls.

carousel_items: Can cause drowsiness, headache, dizziness, and dry mouth.
For ADHD: Might take up to 2 weeks to see effects.
For high blood pressure: Check your blood pressure 1 week after starting this medicine, and tell your doctor if it hasn't improved.
If side effects don't go away, talk to your doctor about alternatives.
Don't stop taking this medicine suddenly.

basics.benefits_moa: Clonidine is an alpha-2 agonist. Researchers don't know exactly how it works for ADHD. It works in the brain and lowers the activity of certain stress hormones, but it's not a stimulant like many ADHD medicines.
basics.bottom_line: Clonidine is a non-stimulant option to manage ADHD symptoms and behaviors, but it can lower your blood pressure.
downsides: Can lower blood pressure.
The pill form can make some people sleepy, dizzy, and have dry mouth.
You can't miss doses. Stopping Clonidine suddenly can cause your blood pressure to go up suddenly, which raises the risk of heart attack and stroke.

downsides_processed.orig: Can lower blood pressure.
The pill form can make some people sleepy, dizzy, and have dry mouth.
You can't miss doses. Stopping Clonidine suddenly can cause your blood pressure to go up suddenly, which raises the risk of heart attack and stroke.

upsides: Can be used alone or together with a stimulant-type medicine to treat ADHD.
In studies, it improved attention span and lowered hyperactivity and impulsivity in children and adolescents ages 6 to 17.
Also treats blood pressure and some nervous system and psychiatric conditions.

upsides_processed.orig: Can be used alone or together with a stimulant-type medicine to treat ADHD.

Also treats blood pressure and some nervous system and psychiatric conditions.

drugs.one_liner: Treats ADHD and lowers blood pressure.
drugs.name: Kapvay

carousel_items_processed.orig: Can cause drowsiness, headache, dizziness, and dry mouth.
For ADHD: Might take up to 2 weeks to see effects.
For high blood pressure: Check your blood pressure 1 week after starting this medicine, and tell your doctor if it hasn't improved.
If side effects don't go away, talk to your doctor about alternatives.
Don't stop taking this medicine suddenly.

risks_warnings.title: Withdrawal (rebound hypertension)
risks_warnings.description: Stopping Clonidine suddenly can cause agitation, headache, tremors, and a sudden rise of blood pressure that can produce complications. Clonidine should be stopped over 2-4 days with the supervision of a doctor. If using with a beta blocker medicine, slowly stop the beta blocker first before stopping Clonidine.

description_processed.orig: Stopping Clonidine suddenly can cause agitation, headache, tremors, and a sudden rise of blood pressure that can produce complications. Clonidine should be stopped over 2-4 days with the supervision of a doctor. If using with a beta blocker medicine, slowly stop the beta blocker first before stopping Clonidine.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Clonidine impairs your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert

description_processed.orig: Clonidine impairs your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

risks_warnings.title: Low heart rate (bradycardia)
risks_warnings.description: Clonidine can lower your heart rate too much. Talk to your doctor if you continue to feel dizzy, tired or getting out  of breath doing things you normally can do after using Clonidine for a week.
risk_factors: Using other medicine(s) that slows the heart

description_processed.orig: Clonidine can lower your heart rate too much. Talk to your doctor if you continue to feel dizzy, tired or getting out  of breath doing things you normally can do after using Clonidine for a week.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure (hypotension)
risks_warnings.description: Clonidine can lower your blood pressure. Monitor your blood pressure in the first week of taking Clonidine. Let your doctor know if you continue to feel dizzy after 1 week of use.

carousel_items: Needs to be taken every day for 2 to 3 weeks to see the full effect of the medication.
It's important to keep taking Clomipramine even when you feel your symptoms are getting better.
Take it with food and/or at bedtime to decrease the potential side effects.
Tell your doctor if you notice sudden mood changes or unusual thoughts.
If you decide to stop taking Clomipramine, work with your doctor to slowly get off this medicine to avoid getting withdrawal symptoms.

basics.benefits_moa: Clomipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). It treats obsessive-compulsive disorder by affecting the levels of serotonin and norepinephrine in your brain.
basics.bottom_line: Clomipramine is helpful in treating OCD, but it can have a lot of side effects.
downsides: It's more likely to cause side effects like dizziness, drowsiness, weight gain, and constipation compared to other medicines in this class.
Can cause sexual performance problems in men.
Increases the risk of falls, especially when used in the elderly.

risks_warnings.title: Suicidal thoughts or behavior
risks_warnings.description: Clomipramine may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior. Watch for worsening depression or any unusual changes in mood or behavior, especially during the first few months of treatment or when the dose changes. Report anything concerning to a doctor immediately. Clomipramine is not approved for use in children younger than age 10 years.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Clomipramine lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful and avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert

description_processed.orig: Clomipramine lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful and avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

risks_warnings.title: Serotonin syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Serotonin syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition caused when there's too much serotonin active in the brain. Your risk goes up if you use Clomipramine with other medications that affect serotonin (other antidepressants, lithium, triptans, St. John's wort). Symptoms include fast heart rate, sweating, muscle stiffness or spasms, fever, and confusion. Get medical attention right away if you have symptoms.
risk_factors: Using other medications that affect serotonin

risks_warnings.title: Seizure
risks_warnings.description: Clomipramine can make it more likely for you to have a seizure. It is generally not recommended if you have a history of seizures or other risk factors.

risks_warnings.title: Withdrawal
risks_warnings.description: Stopping Clomipramine suddenly may cause withdrawal symptoms such as nausea, anxiety, agitation, flu-like symptoms, trouble sleeping, and dizziness. Withdrawal symptoms usually occur within 3-5 days of stopping the medication, and go away within 1-2 weeks. Work with your doctor to gradually reduce your dose.

description_processed.orig: Stopping Clomipramine suddenly may cause withdrawal symptoms such as nausea, anxiety, agitation, flu-like symptoms, trouble sleeping, and dizziness. risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Clomipramine commonly cause a sudden drop in blood pressure, especially when you change positions, such as going from sitting to standing. This is called orthostatic hypotension. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change position slowly until your body is used to the medicine. Be careful since you can feel dizzy or fall. If symptoms continues for more than a week, you may need to change the dose or medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems

carousel_items: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen is a medicine that's used for short-term moderate to severe pain, usually no more than 10 days. Talk to your doctor if your pain lasts longer than 10 days.
Takes about 10 to 20 minutes to start working and can last about 4 to 8 hours.
Can cause headache, constipation, nausea, drowsiness, and dizziness.
Don't drink alcohol with Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen.
Can cause stomach ulcers or bleeding. Don't take it with other blood-thinning medicines without talking to your doctor first.
Take with food or milk to help prevent upset stomach.

basics.benefits_moa: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen is a combination medicine with two pain relievers. One is an opioid that blocks pain receptors in the brain; the other is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that prevents inflammation.
basics.bottom_line: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen works well for moderate to severe pain, but it shouldn't be used long-term.
downsides: Not used for long-term pain or for conditions like osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.
Can cause serious heart and stomach problems. The risk goes up the longer you take it, but problems can happen at any time. Don't take Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen any longer than your doctor recommends.
Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen raises your risk of bleeding, especially when taken with other blood-thinning medicines.
You can experience withdrawal symptoms if you suddenly stop taking Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen.
Not a good choice if you have high blood pressure or kidney, liver, or stomach problems.

downsides_processed.orig: Not used for long-term pain or for conditions like osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.

Not a good choice if you have high blood pressure or kidney, liver, or stomach problems.

upsides: Effective option to relieve short-term moderate to severe pain.
Provides better pain control since Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen is a combination medicine that works in two different ways.
Can cause less sleepiness than other similar medicines.
Available as a generic and comes in different strengths.

risks_warnings.title: Heart attack or stroke
risks_warnings.description: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. The risk can increase the longer you take it. Talk to your doctor about taking the lowest dose that works for you for the shortest time possible.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Hydrocodone/Ibuprofen can cause serious stomach problems, such as ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. These problems can be life-threatening and can cause death. The risk can increase the longer you take it, but it can happen at any time. Watch out for blood or dark-colored stools. This can be a medical emergency and you should get help right away.

carousel_items: Fentanyl should only be used for people whose pain is not controlled by other opioid medications for at least one week.
For pain, the patch takes 12 hours to start working and all other forms start working in 30 minutes or less.
If using the patch, keep it away from heat sources like heating pads, or else it'll cause the medication to be unsafely released into your skin.
Never stop taking Fentanyl suddenly or else you'll have withdrawal effects. To stop taking it, you'll need to lower your dose slowly.
Never drink alcohol when using Fentanyl.
Just one dose can be harmful or fatal to children, so store and dispose of this medication in a way that children can't get to it.

basics.benefits_moa: Fentanyl is an opioid (narcotic) medicine that works in the brain to lower pain perception.
basics.bottom_line: Fentanyl is an excellent pain reliever, but should only be used by people  who've tried other opioid pain medications and still need more relief.
downsides: Fentanyl isn't for everyone. It's a really strong pain medication and taking too much can be deadly.
It doesn't provide quick pain relief.
Often causes drowsiness and constipation. If using it long-term, use a stool softener.
Like all opioids, don't use when pregnant, since the baby can become dependent on it and have withdrawal symptoms after birth.
Shouldn't be used for people with breathing problems (like asthma and COPD), a slow heart rate, or in the elderly.
If using the patch, you won't be able to get the medicine out of your body quickly in case of an overdose.

downsides_processed.orig: Fentanyl isn't for everyone. It's a really strong pain medication and taking too much can be deadly.
It doesn't provide quick pain relief.

Like all opioids, don't use when pregnant, since the baby can become dependent on it and have withdrawal symptoms after birth.
Shouldn't be used for people with breathing problems (like asthma and COPD), a slow heart rate, or in the elderly.
If using the patch, you won't be able to get the medicine out of your body quickly in case of an overdose.

upsides: It's used for people who have tried other opioid medications, but still need stronger pain relief.
Fentanyl is stronger than morphine, works quickly, and doesn't cause as many stomach problems.
It's available in many dosage forms, including a patch, injection, film, nasal spray, and lollipop.
The Fentanyl patch provides long-term pain relief and lowers the number of times you need to take pain medications each day.

drugs.name: fentanyl

carousel_items_processed.orig: Fentanyl should only be used for people whose pain is not controlled by other opioid medications for at least one week.
For pain, the patch takes 12 hours to start working and all other forms start working in 30 minutes or less.
If using the patch, keep it away from heat sources like heating pads, or else it'll cause the medication to be unsafely released into your skin.
Never stop taking Fentanyl suddenly or else you'll have withdrawal effects. To stop taking it, you'll need to lower your dose slowly.
Never drink alcohol when using Fentanyl.
Just one dose can be harmful or fatal to children, so store and dispose of this medication in a way that children can't get to it.

risks_warnings.title: Death from lack of oxygen to the body (respiratory depression)
risks_warnings.description: Taking too much Fentanyl can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. Fentanyl should be swallowed whole, don't ever crush or chew. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Fentanyl. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes. Always check with your doctor before starting any new medicines or supplements.
risk_factors: Current use of medicine that affects liver enzyme CYP 3A4
People with not enough thyroid hormones

description_processed.orig: Taking too much Fentanyl can cause irregular or slow breathing that can put you in a coma and can cause death. Fentanyl should be swallowed whole, don't ever crush or chew. If your lips and fingers start turning blue from low oxygen, see a doctor immediately. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that reverses the effects of Fentanyl. Don't take more than your doctor prescribes. Always check with your doctor before starting any new medicines or supplements.

risks_warnings.title: Death from overdose
risks_warnings.description: Even one dose of Fentanyl can be too much for children. Keep the medicine out of reach from children. If you suspect your child has taken Fentanyl, watch for decreased activity, extreme tiredness, and lips and fingers turning blue from low oxygen. Go to a hospital immediately and the doctors can give a medicine that reverses the effects of Fentanyl until the effects wear off.

risks_warnings.title: Death in newborn babies from opioid withdrawal (Neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome)
risks_warnings.description: Let your doctor know if you have used Fentanyl during pregnancy. Your baby may need special care after birth from experts in this area.

description_processed.orig: Let your doctor know if you have used Fentanyl during pregnancy. Your baby may need special care after birth from experts in this area.

risks_warnings.title: Tolerance, dependence, and addiction
risks_warnings.description: Extended-release and long-acting opioid pain relievers like Fentanyl have a greater risk of addiction, abuse, misuse, overdose, and death. Your body can develop tolerance to Fentanyl, which means that more medicine is needed to treat the same pain. You may become physically dependent on Fentanyl if you have been using it continuously for 2 to 3 weeks or longer, which means that you'll feel withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it. You can avoid withdrawal by weaning off of the medication very slowly with the help of a doctor. Take only the prescribed dose. People with a history of drug abuse shouldn't take Fentanyl if an alternative medicine is available.
risk_factors: Taking more than the prescribed dose
